Our task is to make that agenda relevant to the 2020s and 2030s: to deliver economic justice, social justice and climate justice.

That is a huge task.

This leadership contest can only be one part of it.

Those are the pillars on which we can build a radical agenda for the future.

Inequalities of every type – power, education, health and wealth – are now so ingrained that only a fundamental shift can address them.

We are an anti-austerity party. We believe in common ownership. We want to build a more peaceful world through a human-rights based foreign policy. We must hardwire the Green New Deal into every part of our politics.

We now need to provide an effective opposition to Boris Johnson.

We need to start winning elections again – starting with the local elections in May, building to 2024.

We won’t do that by abandoning our values or the radicalism we have rediscovered.

When Labour is united, we can achieve anything.

The NHS, the minimum wage, the Equal Pay Act, peace in Northern Ireland: impossible dreams made possible by Labour governments.

I’ve spent my life fighting for justice, standing up for the powerless and against the powerful.

I’m now standing to be leader of the Labour Party because I believe I can help unite our movement, take on the Tories and build a better future.

However, it needs courage from world leaders and a human rights approach to foreign policy that priorities peace, justice and reconciliation.

Trump’s actions make that so much harder to achieve and risk escalating not reducing violence. 

The international community needs to re-engage, not isolate Iran. The nuclear deal agreed after years of painstaking diplomacy shows that a different approach is possible.

Trumps’ actions are as irresponsible as they are counterproductive. 

Having wholeheartedly opposed the illegal war in Iraq 17 years ago, I am acutely aware of the additional responsibility we have to the Iraqi people to help them secure the safety and stability of their country.

The Government’s response to Donald Trump’s actions is not good enough.

If anyone has any doubts about where Boris Johnson’s proposals take us, this lays bare that the end destination is a damaging right-wing project, which will rip apart our relationship with the EU and replace it with a US-style economy. https://t.co/F3A5M9FWGi

Labour cannot support this deal. If Boris Johnson has confidence in his deal, he should put it back to the people in a public vote against remain - and that is an argument we will be making on Saturday. 10/
Labour will not support a flawed Brexit deal that harms jobs, rights and living standards. This deal will unquestionably do that. 9/
Instead, the level playing field provisions only last until the end of transition with a warning shot from the EU about the impact this will have on (reduced) access to EU markets. 8/
The level playing field commitments are significantly weaker: no longer building on the measures in the old Withdrawal Agreement, which provided for dynamic alignment in certain areas. 7/
On services, the PD offers nothing beyond the weak provisions in the Theresa May deal. Nor has there been any progress on the question of agencies and our future security relationship. 6/

This inevitably means there will be new trade barriers with the EU and additional checks at borders. The PD is explicit about this. And the Johnson deal makes it easier for a Tory Government to cut rights and standards. 5/

Rather than strengthening the Political Declaration (PD) along the lines Labour argued, the political direction of travel under Johnson is to a distant economic relationship with the EU. It rules out a new Customs Union and a close future relationship with the Single Market. 4/

Having reviewed what has been agreed, it is clear that the Johnson deal is a far worse deal than Theresa May’s deal. It paves the way for a decade of deregulation. It gives Johnson licence to slash workers’ rights, environmental standards and consumer protections. 3/
Labour’s concerns with Theresa May’s deal were not principally about the backstop. They were about the Political Declaration and our future relationship with the EU after Brexit. 2/

Warm welcome for @Keir_Starmer in #Swansea #Wales this afternoon from @WelshLabour members + trade unionists - and a huge thank you from Keir to @WelshLabour AMs and Councillors for the difference they are making in Government in Wales 👏👍🌹🏴󠁧󠁢󠁷󠁬󠁳󠁿#AnotherFutureIsPossible https://t.co/eRXougILmv

We were delighted to welcome @Keir_Starmer today to Usdaw’s National Seminar in Manchester. Thanks to Keir for taking the time to come and speak to Usdaw officials and answer so many questions. https://t.co/RC7qnJEONK

Trump’s so-called ‘peace plan’ is a farce. It is inconsistent with international law and human rights protections. 

Our Government should unequivocally condemn it because it will cause even more suffering for the Palestinian people who have already endured so much.
I don’t often tweet but seeing @Keir_Starmer speak in Edinburgh tonight has given me so much hope for the future of our party. 🌹

We have written to all our branches to ensure our membership data is ready and up to date as we start the process of re-balloting every postal worker for industrial action. 

This is going to be one hell of a fight. Let our members know you are with them by sharing this tweet 👊
Community backs @Keir_Starmer for Leader of the Labour Party https://t.co/BEcVS7hoS5

Heartfelt thanks to everyone in the Labour Party, especially the other leadership candidates, and to everyone beyond the Labour Party for the support and kindness you have extended to my family and me in what has been - and sadly will continue to be - a very difficult time.

Can’t believe I’m having to write this, cos this is basic...There are over a million Chinese, East Asians and those of mixed heritage like myself living in the UK and we are not responsible for the actions of the Chinese Govt, nor are we spies or a takeaway. 1/3 #chineseforlabour

The battle to protect and advance equality is getting tougher, with reproductive rights at sharp end (watch what trump has been doing to see what’s coming our way) help make sure the next labour leader is at the front of the fight, not missing in action: https://t.co/aKXxl9UsND

Our task is to make that agenda relevant to the 2020s and 2030s: to deliver economic justice, social justice and climate justice.

That is a huge task.

This leadership contest can only be one part of it.

Those are the pillars on which we can build a radical agenda for the future.

Inequalities of every type – power, education, health and wealth – are now so ingrained that only a fundamental shift can address them.

We are an anti-austerity party. We believe in common ownership. We want to build a more peaceful world through a human-rights based foreign policy. We must hardwire the Green New Deal into every part of our politics.

We now need to provide an effective opposition to Boris Johnson.

We need to start winning elections again – starting with the local elections in May, building to 2024.

We won’t do that by abandoning our values or the radicalism we have rediscovered.

When Labour is united, we can achieve anything.

The NHS, the minimum wage, the Equal Pay Act, peace in Northern Ireland: impossible dreams made possible by Labour governments.

I’ve spent my life fighting for justice, standing up for the powerless and against the powerful.

I’m now standing to be leader of the Labour Party because I believe I can help unite our movement, take on the Tories and build a better future.

Labour will not support a flawed Brexit deal that harms jobs, rights and living standards. This deal will unquestionably do that. 9/
Instead, the level playing field provisions only last until the end of transition with a warning shot from the EU about the impact this will have on (reduced) access to EU markets. 8/
The level playing field commitments are significantly weaker: no longer building on the measures in the old Withdrawal Agreement, which provided for dynamic alignment in certain areas. 7/
On services, the PD offers nothing beyond the weak provisions in the Theresa May deal. Nor has there been any progress on the question of agencies and our future security relationship. 6/

This inevitably means there will be new trade barriers with the EU and additional checks at borders. The PD is explicit about this. And the Johnson deal makes it easier for a Tory Government to cut rights and standards. 5/

Rather than strengthening the Political Declaration (PD) along the lines Labour argued, the political direction of travel under Johnson is to a distant economic relationship with the EU. It rules out a new Customs Union and a close future relationship with the Single Market. 4/

Having reviewed what has been agreed, it is clear that the Johnson deal is a far worse deal than Theresa May’s deal. It paves the way for a decade of deregulation. It gives Johnson licence to slash workers’ rights, environmental standards and consumer protections. 3/
Labour’s concerns with Theresa May’s deal were not principally about the backstop. They were about the Political Declaration and our future relationship with the EU after Brexit. 2/

Turning the content of the 14 January letter from Donald Tusk and Jean Claude Juncker into a joint interpretative declaration does not change that. Nor in my view does anything else agreed last night. 6/
However, the Withdrawal Agreement does not include a mechanism for unilateral exit from – or termination of – the backstop (or any other part of the Agreement) even where bad faith is made out. 5/

Under Article 178 of the Withdrawal Agreement, if either side is found to have acted in breach of the good faith/best endeavours obligation, the strongest remedy is “temporary suspension” of parts of the Agreement to force the other side back to the negotiating table. 4/
In that advice, the Attorney General said that under international law the backstop “would endure indefinitely until a superseding agreement takes its place in whole or in part.” 3/
Having studied the documents, I would be surprised if they are sufficient to enable the Attorney General to change the central plank of his December legal advice. 2/

Today we remember those brave protesters.

Third, the PM has said the two documents should be treated as one. 

On 14 January she said “the link between [the two documents] means that the commitments of one cannot be banked without the commitments of the other. The EU has been clear that they come as a package.” 4/

Second, in their letter of 14 January Presidents Tusk and Juncker said: “As for the link between the Withdrawal Agreement and the Political Declaration….it can be made clear that these two documents, while being of a different nature, are part of the same negotiated package.” 3/

First, the Article 50 process explicitly states that the EU and member state must negotiate an agreement “setting out the arrangements for its withdrawal, taking account of the framework for its future relationship with the Union”. 2/
There are four key reasons why you cannot separate the Withdrawal Agreement from the Political Declaration. 1/
